{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = James Caan |honorific_suffix = {{postnominals|country=GBR|CBE}} |image = James Caan (entrepreneur).jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Nazim Khan{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2013/jun/06/james-caan-dragons-den-business|title=James Caan: 'No parent is not going to help their children'|first=Rupert|last=Neate|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|date=6 June 2013|accessdate=28 March 2018}}
[[Urdu]]: جيمس خان |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|12|28|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]] |residence = [[London]], [[England]] |nationality = Pakistani-British |other_names = |known_for = [[Business]], [[Recruitment]], ''[[Dragons' Den (UK)|Dragons' Den]]'' |occupation = Entrepreneur |networth = £95 million{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/dragons-den-entrepreneur-james-caan-7367074|title=Dragons' Den entrepreneur James Caan splits with wife after 32 year marriage|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=13 February 2016|author1=Matthew Drake|author2=Janine Yaqoob|accessdate=8 July 2017}} |spouse = {{marriage|Aisha Caan|1983|2016|reason=divorced}} |children = Hannah
Jemma |parents = |relations = |signature = |website = {{Official URL}} }} '''James Caan''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|CBE}} (born '''Nazim Khan''', 28 December 1960) is a [[British Pakistanis|British-Pakistani]] [[entrepreneur]] and television personality. He is best known as a former investor on the BBC television programme ''[[Dragons' Den (UK)|Dragons’ Den]]'', in which he was one of the Dragons from 2007 to 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dragonsden/about/history.shtml|title=History of the Den|publisher=[[BBC Online]]}} More recently, he has hosted ''The Business Class'' on [[CNBC]], a series which sees him joined by experts from a cross-section of industries to analyse and advise innovative UK [[small and medium enterprises]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/49037243|title=The Business Class|publisher=[[CNBC]]}} He is also Chairman of the UK Government's [[Start Up Loans Scheme]], which supports entrepreneurs with funding and mentoring to start their own business.{{cite news|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-2312176/|title=Former Dragons' Den judge James Caan helps 3,000 young entrepreneurs roar|publisher=MailOnline|date=20 April 2013}} Caan initially achieved success in the recruitment industry, founding the recruitment company Alexander Mann in 1985, which he sold in 2002. In 1993, he co-founded the executive head-hunting firm Humana International, in which he sold his stake in 1999. He is also the founder and current CEO of the UK-based private equity firm [[Hamilton Bradshaw]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/smallbusiness/article-3610338/|title=Ex-Dragon James Caan's Start-up Secrets: I'm happy to admit I’ve had many failures throughout my career - accepting failure is as important as being successful'|publisher=MailOnline|date=30 May 2016|author=Eleanor Lawrie}} In 2013, he was named Chairman of the Year at the International Business Awards.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebiponline.co.uk/bip/james-caan-awarded-chairman-of-the-year-at-the-2013/|title=James Caan awarded Chairman of the Year at the 2013…|date=19 September 2013}} Caan has been involved in a number of charitable activities and founded the James Caan Foundation in 2006. ==Early life and education== Born in [[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]], Pakistan, Caan's family emigrated to the United Kingdom when he was two years old. His father came to the UK without any money or knowing the language but was able to build a successful business from scratch. He subsequently established a clothing company in [[Brick Lane]], east London. Caan's father had intended him to join the family business once his formal education was completed, but Caan decided he wanted to find his own way in the world. At 16, before he had begun his [[GCE Ordinary Level|O-Levels]], he left home and moved to a flat in [[Kensington]]. This led to Caan's being estranged from his father for many years. Other than a Saturday job at Mr Buyright, Caan had no formal experience of work and so went to a recruitment agency to find some. His first job was door to door sales, which he found tiring. At this point, he knew he wanted to work in an office. He went back to the recruitment agency and asked for something that was indoors and saw a job working for [[Grand Metropolitan]]. He worked for several recruitment companies and started a fashion boutique with his wife before deciding he wanted to start his own company.{{cite book|title=The Real Deal: My Story from Brick Lane to Dragons' Den|publisher=[[Virgin Books]]|author=James Caan|year=2008|isbn=9781905264452|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DaQnAQAAMAAJ}} Caan started his own recruitment company in the early 1980s. His first office was in [[Pall Mall, London|Pall Mall]] but was so small that the door could not be fully opened as it was blocked by his desk.{{cite web|url=http://www.startups.co.uk/james-caan.html|title=James Caan The Dragons’ Den panellist on gap years, what makes the ideal investment and his unwavering obsession with windows|publisher=[[UK Startup Awards]]|date=17 April 2008|accessdate=1 December 2012}} He purposely chose the prestigious address to add credibility to his business.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/fameandfortune/10106803/James-Caan-To-succeed-you-have-to-be-ready-to-lose.html|title=James Caan: 'To succeed, you have to be ready to lose' |work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|first=Ewing|last=Sarah|date=9 June 2013|accessdate=29 March 2018}} Caan did not excel at school and did not attend university as an undergraduate, but graduated from the 7-week Advanced Management Program at [[Harvard Business School]] in 2003.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/yourbusiness/3161421/How-money-stopped-mattering-for-Dragons-Den-mogul-James-Caan.html|title=How money stopped mattering for Dragons' Den mogul James Caan|author=Celia Walden|date=8 October 2008}} ==Career== ===Business=== He founded the recruitment company Alexander Mann in 1987. In 1993 Caan co-founded the executive headhunting firm Humana International with Doug Bugie, eventually growing the business to over 147 offices in 30 countries. In the same year, Caan launched the trade magazine ''Recruitment International'', which he later sold in 2000. In 1996 Caan co-founded the business process outsourcing company AMS with Rosaleen Blair. Caan subsequently sold his interests in AMS in 2002. In 1999, Caan sold Humana International to CDI International, a New York listed company. Later in that year, Caan sold a minority stake in Alexander Mann Group to private equity firm [[Advent International]]. In 2002 Caan sold his interests in Alexander Mann, which by that time had a turnover of around £130m. In 2004 Caan established the London-based private equity firm, Hamilton Bradshaw. Hamilton Bradshaw is an investment group that specialises in Seed Capital and Growth Capital for recruitment businesses. Hamilton Bradshaw has invested in more than 30 portfolio businesses across 46 offices in the UK, and in 2014 reported more than £300 million in turnover. Recruitment Entrepreneur is the Seed Capital arm of Hamilton Bradshaw which provides the seed funding and support for ambitious, experienced recruitment professionals to start, or scale, their own recruitment ventures. In June 2013, Caan gave an interview in which he criticised parents who aid their children with finding jobs and don't let them 'stand on their own two feet', he was accused of hypocrisy when it emerged that he had employed his own daughter in one of his companies.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/jun/04/james-caan-daughters-nepotism|title=James Caan: social mobility tsar denies nepotism but employs his daughter|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=5 June 2013|author=Peter Walker|accessdate=6 June 2013}} Caan responded that his daughter's recruitment process had been "rigorous", and stated that the outburst around this revelation would not detract from his six-month effort to campaign for a breakdown of employment barriers.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-22716241|title=TV experts turned tsars: How did they do?|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=6 June 2013|author=Brian Wheeler}} However, in an interview with [[The Independent]] Caan admitted, "‘I would find it very difficult not to help my child’".{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/was-social-mobility-tsar-and-former-dragons-den-star-james-caan-right-to-give-his-kids-a-helping-8650320.html|title=Was social mobility tsar and former Dragons' Den star James Caan right to give his kids a helping hand?|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=7 June 2013|author=Chloe Hamilton}} In the same year, he invested in the managed office provider Avanta, which he sold three years later to the private equity company Kenmore. In 2007 Hamilton Bradshaw acquired the recruitment specialist Eden Brown and Caan sold his remaining interest in Alexander Mann Group to [[Graphite Private Equity]] in a management buy-out led by Rosaleen Blair. In 2009 Caan launched HBRIDA, with his then business partner Helen Reynolds (ex ACEO of the REC). HBRIDA worked with SME recruitment agencies to help them achieve growth and led them to an exit. Reynolds performed a management buyout of the business in March 2012. In 2010 Caan launched The Entrepreneurs Business Academy and became a non–Executive Director of [[McCann (company)|McCann London]]. In 2011 Caan founded Hamilton Bradshaw Venture Partners. In 2012/13, Caan launched Hamilton Bradshaw Real Estate (HBRE) to invest in "disruptive property start-ups".{{cite web|url=http://www.primeresi.com/looking-for-the-next-rightmove-primeresi-meets-faisal-butt/14342/|title=Looking for the next Rightmove: PrimeResi meets Faisal Butt, property’s venture capitalist with the Caan-do attitude|publisher=PrimeResi|date=15 April 2013|author=Matt Crofton}} James Caan was recognised in the 2015 New Year Honours List, with a Commander of the Order of the British Empire for services to entrepreneurship and charitable services through the James Caan Foundation. Caan, Chairman of Start Up Loans, which has supported thousands of people with funding and mentoring to start their own business was “delighted and privileged” to receive the accolade. This award is recognition for the 23,000 new businesses set up through the scheme as well as his philanthropic work which has helped thousands since the floods hit Pakistan in July 2010. ===Television=== In 2007 Caan joined the panel of ''Dragons' Den'' judges for the fifth series of the show. [[Hilary Devey]] replaced James Caan on Dragons Den in 2012. Through his role on Dragons’ Den, Caan worked with [[Children in Need]] for many years. In 2008, Children in Need filmed a ‘Youth Dragons Den’. ‘Look for Loneliness’ was his initiative to help reduce bullying and get children to understand what it is like to feel isolated. Caan went on to work with Children in Need in 2009, helping to renovate a Community Centre for young people to visit before and after school. In 2008, in aid of [[Comic Relief]], Caan teamed up with the other presenters of Dragons Den for a special edition of the programme titled ‘Victorians Dragons’ Den’. In December 2009 Caan joined the [[Sport Relief]] team on a four-day trip to Kenya. In 2012, he was approached by CNBC to host The Business Class, a series which sees him joined by experts from a cross-section of industries, looking at the challenges and opportunities faced by UK SMEs. Each 30-minute episode featured an innovative business which was seeking guidance to help it grow in the marketplace. The popularity of the series saw it recommissioned for a second series in October 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2013/10/03/james-caan-to-host-business-series-on-cnbc-to-help-smes.html|title=James Caan To Host Business Series On CNBC To Help SMEs|publisher=CNBC|date=3 October 2013}} In 2014 Caan joined the UKs largest business magazine Business Matters as a columnist{{cite web|url=http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/author/james-caan/|title=James Caan, Columnist at|publisher=[[Business Matters]]}} ===Social media=== In 2011, James Caan launched his mobile app 'James Caan Business Secrets'. Within weeks of launching the app rose to Number 1 in the iTunes chart and later became the fastest downloaded Business app of the year. It has regularly been ranked as a top business app by various publications, it has received over 250,000 downloads and has more than 1.5 million sessions.{{cite web|url=http://www.recruitment-international.co.uk/news/james-caan-mentors-1m-on-linkedin-23076.htm|title=James Caan mentors 1m on LinkedIn|publisher=[[Recruitment International]]|date=10 June 2014|accessdate=25 June 2014}} In 2014, Caan relaunched the latest version of his app to include three free audiobooks as well as additional chapters with tangible advice to help people start, grow or exit businesses. It focuses on key issues such as raising finance, marketing, growth and expansion.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/app/james-caan-business-secrets/id430824440?mt=8|title=James Caan Business Secrets|publisher=[[iTunes]]|date=8 June 2014|accessdate=25 June 2014}} In October 2012, James Caan was approached by [[LinkedIn]] to be one of 150 LinkedIn Influencers. By June 2014, Caan surpassed 1 million followers on LinkedIn.{{cite web|url=http://blog.hootsuite.com/first-million-linkedin-followers-james-caan/|title=What I Learned From My First Million LinkedIn Followers|publisher=[[Hootsuite]]|date=6 June 2014|author=James Caan|accessdate=24 June 2014}} In late June, Caan surpassed U.S. President Barack Obama and UK Prime minister David Cameron in the number of followers, making him the 7th most followed person on LinkedIn.{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/today/influencers?trk=inf_bdg_profile|title=LinkedIn Influencer List|publisher=[[LinkedIn]]|date=24 June 2014|accessdate=24 June 2014}} As a LinkedIn influencer, James blogs about career advice and provides tips for entrepreneurs and small business owners on growing their business and leadership. ===Author=== Caan has written several books on business and his life. The first book covered his life story and was published in 2008 called 'The Real Deal - My Story from Brick Lane to Dragons' Den'. Following publications focused on business and entrepreneurship with 'Get the Job You Really Want', 'Start Your Business in 7 Days' and most recently, 'Get the Life You Really Want'. ==Public sector== Caan has been involved with the British Government and their agencies on a number of initiatives related to UK business for many years. These include The Government Entrepreneur’s Forum {{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/11/15/uk-government-creates-entrepreneurs-forum-advisory-board-which-ones-are-just-celebrities/|title=UK government creates Entrepreneurs' Forum advisory board. Which ones are just celebrities?|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|date=15 November 2010|author=Mike Butcher|accessdate=17 June 2013}} and The [[Department for International Development| Department for International Development (DFID)]] where he worked on the relief effort after the [[Pakistan flood|2010 Pakistan flood]]. ===The Start Up Loans Company=== In May 2012, Caan was approached by the government to become Chairman of the ''[[Start Up Loans Scheme|Start Up Loans]]'' initiative. The aim is to support young people with funding and mentoring to start up new businesses in the UK. Over £112 million of loans were to be offered to 18- to 30-year-olds over a 3-year period. James and his board of entrepreneur ambassadors head up the government scheme, providing loans of around £2,500 to the 18- to 30-year-olds to start their own businesses.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-20892658|title=Start-up loans scheme expanded|publisher=BBC News|date=3 January 2013|accessdate=15 February 2013}} Originally, the goal of Start Up Loans was to help 1,000 businesses obtain government and private sector investments to fund these new ventures, however as of 2014, James Caan has helped provide funding and mentorship to more than 18,000 start ups.{{cite web|url=http://www.james-caan.com/about-james/government/|title=Start Up Loans|publisher=james-caan.com}} ==Charitable activities== ===The James Caan Foundation=== Caan founded the James Caan Foundation (JCF) in 2006 after he took a ‘gap year’ to visit his homeland of Pakistan. The JCF supports charities in the UK and seeks to promote greater awareness of issues facing the developing world, with a primary focus on children's access to education and healthcare. The JCF has funded the construction of a new school at his birthplace [[Lahore]], located in the eastern province of [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]]. Since first purchasing a barren plot of land and opening the 16-classroom school in 2005, the TCF School, named after Caan’s father, educates over 420 children aged between 5-11.{{cite web|url=http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/10094374.James_Caan___If_anyone_wasn___t_going_to_make_it_then_I_should_have_topped_that_list__/|title=James Caan: 'If anyone wasn’t going to make it then I should have topped that list!'|publisher=''Asian Image''|date=7 December 2012|accessdate=17 June 2013}} ===2010 Pakistan floods=== In July 2010, Caan flew to Pakistan immediately after the [[2010 Pakistan floods|worst flooding in the country's history]] and personally purchased, prepared and delivered emergency food parcels to families in the Northern village of [[Nowshera, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Nowshera]]. Upon his return to the UK Caan partnered with [[UNICEF]] to provide urgent food, medical supplies and water and hygiene kits to 1,000 families in the affected area. Caan also undertook an extensive media outreach campaign and his trip was widely covered in national newspapers. After just two weeks, Caan had raised £100,000 for UNICEF. Caan and the James Caan Foundation subsequently undertook a project to rebuild a village in Pakistan, including schools, hospitals, homes and all infrastructure and water supplies. Aid agencies including UNICEF, [[Oxfam]], [[Islamic Relief]], [[Muslim Hands]] and [[Mosaic Foundation|Mosaic]] were also involved in the project.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/pakistan/7968856/James-Caan-the-Dragon-humbled-by-Pakistan-floods-disaster.html|title=James Caan: the Dragon humbled by Pakistan floods disaster|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=27 August 2010}} Caan drew criticism when he was caught on camera offering to buy a baby from a family that was a victim of the [[Pakistan flood|2010 Pakistan flood]]. Caan insisted the offer had been made with good intentions, but stated that he regretted the incident and described his behaviour as "clearly wrong".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11605927|title=Dragons' Den James Caan 'regrets offer to buy baby'|publisher=BBC Online|date=22 October 2010|accessdate=22 October 2010}} Caan was later filmed saying: "If there's an opportunity to give a life a chance of survival, it's more an emotional response than a rational decision.", "What I have to remember is that I am here to build a village. That child belongs to that family".{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/dragons-den-tycoon-james-caan-1073489|title=Dragons' Den tycoon James Caan apologises after trying to buy baby on TV|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|date=23 October 2010|accessdate=6 November 2012}} ===Other=== Caan is involved with and supports other charities including [[The Prince's Trust]], [[Marie Curie]], [[Mosaic Foundation|Mosaic]], [[CARE International|Care Foundation]] and the [[NSPCC]]. In 2009 Caan was appointed chairman of [[The Big Issue Company]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/press/enter-the-dragon-carrying-the-big-issue-for-pakistan-1839160.html|title=Enter the Dragon, carrying 'The Big Issue' for Pakistan|date=13 December 2009|author=Matthew Bell}} Caan was appointed [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the 2015 New Year Honours for services to entrepreneurship and charitable services.{{London Gazette|issue=61092|supp=y|page=N8|date=31 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/391413/New_Year_Honours_List_2015.pdf|title=2015 New Year Honours List|date=2 January 2015|format=PDF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102104907/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/391413/New_Year_Honours_List_2015.pdf|archive-date=2 January 2015|dead-url=no}} ==Publications== *2008 - ''The Real Deal'' (autobiography) *2011 - ''Get the Job You Really Want'' *2012 - ''Get the Life you Really Want'' *2012 - ''Start Your Business in 7 Days'' ==Honours== *Honorary doctorate in Business Administration from [[Leeds Met University]] (2009) *Honorary degree from the [[University of East London]] {{cite news|url=http://www.therichest.org/video/james-caan-awarded-an-honorary-doctorate-by-the-university-of-east-london/|title=James Caan awarded an Honorary Doctorate by the University of East London|work=therichest.org|date=6 March 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130617223458/http://www.therichest.org/video/james-caan-awarded-an-honorary-doctorate-by-the-university-of-east-london/|archive-date=17 June 2013|accessdate=17 June 2013|dead-url=yes}} *Honorary doctorate in Business Administration from [[York St John University]] (2010){{cite web|url=https://www.yorksj.ac.uk/about/honorary-graduates/honorary-graduates-2010/|title=Honorary Graduates 2010}} *Honorary doctorate from [[University of Bradford]] (2012) ==Awards and nominations== In January 2013, Caan was awarded the Entrepreneur of the Year award at the [[British Muslim Awards]].{{cite news|url=http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/10197507.Winners_honoured_at_British_Muslim_Awards/|title=Winners honoured at British Muslim Awards|publisher=Asian Image|date=31 January 2013|accessdate=1 November 2015}}Also in 2013, he was named Chairman of the Year at the International Business Awards. In January 2014, he was a finalist for the Entrepreneur of the Year award at the British Muslim Awards.{{cite news|url=http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/united_kingdom/10978079.British_Muslim_Awards_2014_winners/|title=British Muslim Awards 2014 winners|publisher=Asian Image|date=31 January 2014|accessdate=1 November 2015}} In January 2015, he was nominated for the Businessman of the Year award at the British Muslim Awards.{{cite news|url=http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/business/11745550.British_Muslim_Awards_2015_finalists_unveiled/|title=British Muslim Awards 2015 finalists unveiled|publisher=Asian Image|date=23 January 2015|accessdate=1 November 2015}} On 29 October 2015, Caan was listed by UK-based company [[Richtopia]] at number 16 in the list of 100 Most Influential British Entrepreneurs.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/teenage-apprentice-aged-17-ranked-6730716|title=Teenage apprentice aged 17 ranked with Lord Sugar and Sir Richard Branson as top entrepreneur|publisher=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=29 October 2015|author=Martin Bagot|accessdate=29 January 2016}} ==See also== [[List of British Pakistanis]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Caan, James}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Pakistani Muslims]] [[Category:British people of Punjabi descent]] [[Category:Pakistani emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:British expatriates in Monaco]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople of Pakistani descent]] [[Category:British businesspeople of Pakistani descent]] [[Category:Private equity and venture capital investors]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Lahore]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Pakistani expatriates in Monaco]]

{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Jeremy Levin | image= LevinJM_Headshot_FINAL_20161028.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1954}} | birth_place = South Africa | alma_mater = [[Oxford University]], [[Cambridge University]] | nationality = American | occupation = Chairman and ceo, ovid therapeutics inc | children = 2 | spouse = Margery Feldberg (m. 1987) }}
'''Jeremy Levin''' (born 1954) is a South African-born businessman, medical doctor and research scientist. Levin has been recognised for his accomplishments in the biopharmaceutical industry, being named one of the most influential people in the industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fiercebiotech.com/special-reports/25-most-influential-people-biopharma-today/jeremy-levin-25-most-influential-people-b|title=Jeremy Levin - The 25 most influential people in biopharma today {{!}} FierceBiotech|website=www.fiercebiotech.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
==Career== Levin is the chairman and CEO of Ovid Therapeutics Inc., a company dedicated to providing innovative medicines to children and adults with neurological disorders.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ovidrx.com/press-release/ovid-therapeutics-appoints-dr-jeremy-levin-as-chief-executive-officer|title=Ovid Therapeutics Appoints Dr. Jeremy Levin as Chief Executive Officer {{!}} OvidRx|date=2015-04-16|work=OvidRx|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102591288|title=Former Teva CEO's new gig at Ovid Therapeutics|last=Tirrell|first=Meg|date=2015-04-16|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> Ovid’s initial product development programs are focused on orphan and rare diseases of the brain, including [[Angelman syndrome]] and [[Fragile X syndrome]].
Prior to joining Ovid, Levin served as President and CEO of [[Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd.]] (NYSE:TEVA), one of the world’s largest pharmaceutical companies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4170124,00.html|title=Jeremy Levin named new Teva CEO|date=2012-02-01|work=Ynetnews|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en}}</ref><ref>http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-01-03/news/30584630_1_teva-pharmaceutical-industries-shlomo-yanai-cephalon</ref> Previously, he was a member of the Executive Committee of [[Bristol-Myers Squibb]] (NYSE:BMY), where he had global responsibilities for strategy, alliances and transactions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bms.com/press-release/jeremy-levin-joins-bristol-myers-squibb-senior-vice-president-external-science-technol|title=Jeremy Levin Joins Bristol-Myers Squibb as Senior Vice President of External Science, Technology and Licensing {{!}} BMS Newsroom|website=news.bms.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> In this role, he devised and led BMY’s “String of Pearls” business development strategy. This strategy helped drive the transformation of BMY, particularly following the acquisition by Levin of Medarex Inc. in July 2009, which positioned BMY as a leader in [[immunooncology]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://seekingalpha.com/article/838671-bristol-myers-squibb-the-asset-problem-and-the-string-of-pearls|title=Bristol-Myers Squibb: The Asset Problem And The String Of Pearls|last=N|first=Shankar|date=2012-08-30|work=Seeking Alpha|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-01-02/teva-says-jeremy-levin-named-to-succeed-shlomo-yanai-as-ceo|title=Teva’s Levin May Boost Branded Drugs as Copaxone Threat Looms|date=2012-01-02|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bms.com/press-release/partnering-news/bristol-myers-squibb-acquire-medarex|title=Bristol-Myers Squibb to Acquire Medarex {{!}} BMS Newsroom|website=news.bms.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> Prior to this, Levin was Head of Global Business Development and Strategic Alliances at [[Novartis]] (NYSE: NVS), and previously served as chairman and CEO of Cadus Pharmaceuticals, Inc.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.genomeweb.com/rnai/novartis-alnylam-deal-fulfills-long-term-plan-partner-rnai-drug-development|title=For Novartis, Alnylam Deal Fulfills Long-Term Plan to Partner on RNAi Drug Development|work=GenomeWeb|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.secinfo.com/dr4ur.82w6.htm|title=SEC Info - Cadus Corp - ‘S-8 POS’ on 12/23/97|website=www.secinfo.com|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
Levin currently serves on the Boards of Biocon LTD and [[ZappRx]].<ref>http://www.biocon.com/docs/DrLevin_Biocon_BOD.pdf</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://medcitynews.com/2015/04/zapprx-raises-5-6m-series-pharma-companies-take-responsibility-specialty-drug-needs/|title=ZappRX raises $5.6M Series A as pharma becomes more responsive to specialty drug support needs - MedCity News|website=medcitynews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.twst.com/interview/10785|title=Jeremy Levin - Physiome Sciences - The Wall Street Transcript|date=2001-10-12|work=The Wall Street Transcript|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Levin is a frequent speaker at biopharmaceutical conferences where his focus is driving deeper and more direct relationships between companies and patients, ensuring innovation in the biopharmaceutical industry, expanding the role of mergers and acquisitions, globalising the biopharmaceutical industry, and propelling interface of the digital health and biopharmaceutical industries and leadership.<ref>{{Citation|last=חברת טוגדר|title=Jeremy Levin - full speech at the Kellogg-Recanati International EMBA 2013|date=2013-11-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e4cDBjiFV_Y|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
==Early life== Levin was born in South Africa, where his family had a farm, De Hoek Farm, in [[Piketberg]], Western Cape. Following the [[Sharpeville massacre]], he left South Africa and moved to live in Salisbury, [[Rhodesia]] (now Harare, Zimbabwe). His father was a political journalist, who in 1965, was given a day to leave the country. Levin, his mother and brother followed some time later eventually settling in London England where he completed his undergraduate, graduate and medical degrees. Prior to his business experience Levin practised medicine, working at university hospitals including the [[Hammersmith Hospital]] in London, [[Groote Schuur]] in Cape Town, South Africa and [[Hôpitaux universitaires de Genève]], Geneva, Switzerland. Levin, who lives in the USA, has previously lived in South Africa, Zimbabwe, Great Britain, Switzerland and Israel. In 1986, Levin came to America and where he has worked in the biopharmaceutical industry in progressively senior positions.
==Education== Levin was educated first in South Africa and then [[Rhodesia]] (Zimbabwe). As a teenager, his family moved to London, where he attended [[Holland Park School]]. Following graduating from high school, Levin went to Wadham College, [[University of Oxford]], where he gained a First Class BA Honors degree in Zoology, and a Masters of Arts (MA) and doctorate (DPhil) in cell biology and chromatin structure from the [[Oxford University]]'s [[Sir William Dunn School of Pathology]]. He subsequently received an MB, BChir degree (Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery) from the [[University of Cambridge]].
==Personal life== Levin married Margery Feldberg (daughter of Stanley Feldberg, co-founder of [[TJX Companies]]) in 1987 and has two daughters. He is the brother of [[David Levin (businessman)|David Levin]], CEO of [[McGraw-Hill Education]]. He is also the brother of Michal Levin. Levin's mother, Leah Levin OBE, is Hon. Doctor of the [[University of Essex]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.essex.ac.uk/honorary_graduates/|title=Honorary Graduates - Honorary Graduates - University of Essex|website=www.essex.ac.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> She served on the board of the United Nations Association, Anti-Slavery and International Alert, and was Director of [[JUSTICE]] from 1982 to 1992.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thoolen.wordpress.com/2013/10/07/leah-levin-a-human-rights-defender-of-the-first-rank/|title=Leah Levin; a human rights defender of the first rank|date=2013-10-07|work=Hans Thoolen on Human Rights Defenders|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Ms. Levin also served on Boards of Redress, Readers International, and the International Journal of Human Rights.<ref>http://www.redress.org/about-redress/who-we-are</ref>She is the author of UNESCO’s "Human Rights: Questions and Answers," one the world’s widely disseminated books on human rights.<ref>http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0018/001850/185034e.pdf</ref>
==Honours== Levin is the recipient of a number of awards, including:
*FierceBiotech’s one of the most influential people in biopharma<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fiercebiotech.com/special-reports/25-most-influential-people-biopharma-today/jeremy-levin-25-most-influential-people-b|title=Jeremy Levin - The 25 most influential people in biopharma today {{!}} FierceBiotech|website=www.fiercebiotech.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> *The Kermode Prize for work on novel hypertension drugs<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://belsgroup.com/about/bels-advisory-council/|title=British Expats in Life SciencesBritish Expats in Life Sciences {{!}} Strengthening Our United Kingdom of Life Scientists|website=belsgroup.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> *The Albert Einstein Award for Leadership in Life Sciences<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asu.edu/news/stories/200608/20060807_poste.htm|title=ASU Now|website=ASU Now|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> *The B'nai B'rith Award for Distinguished Achievement for commitment to improving global health care<ref>http://cednc.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Life-Science-Conference-2014-Book_FINAL.pdf</ref> *The Officer's Cross of the Order of Merit of the Republic of Hungary<ref>http://isites.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k106493&pageid=icb.page693920</ref>

John Robert Burt | birth_date = {{Birth date|1874|08|27|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Dunedin]], New Zealand | death_place = [[Christchurch]], New Zealand | death_date = {{Death date and age|1933|01|16|1874|08|27|df=yes}} | ru_position = [[Rugby union positions#Back row|Loose forward]] | height = | weight = | allblackid = 117 | allblackno = 81 | ru_nationalteam = {{nowrap|{{ru|New College]] | module = {{Infobox cricketer | child = yes | name = | image = | country = | fullname = | birth_date = | birth_place = | nickname = | heightft = | heightinch = | heightm = | batting = | bowling = | role = Batsman | club1 = [[Otago cricket team|Otago]] | year1 = 1901–09 | type1 = First-class | onetype1 = | debutdate1 = 26 December | debutyear1 = 1901 | debutfor1 = Otago | debutagainst1 = [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]] | lastdate1 = 5 January | lastyear1 = 1909 | lastfor1 = Otago | lastagainst1 = [[Hawke's Bay cricket team|Hawke's Bay]] | deliveries = balls | columns = 1 | column1 = First-class | matches1 = 3 | runs1 = 72 | bat avg1 = 18.00 | 100s/50s1 = 0/0 | top score1 = 27 | hidedeliveries = true | deliveries1 = | wickets1 = | bowl avg1 = | fivefor1 = | tenfor1 = | best bowling1 = | catches/stumpings1 = 2/0 | date = | year = | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/21/21568/21568.html Cricket Archive }} }} '''John Robert Burt''' (27 August 1874 – 16 January 1933) was a New Zealand [[rugby union]] player, cricketer and businessman. He played one match for the [[New Zealand national rugby union team]], made three first-class appearances for the [[Otago cricket team]], and was a branch manager of the engineering firm, A. & T. Burt Ltd, founded by his father.
==Early life and family== Burt was born in [[Dunedin]] on 27 August 1874,<ref name="AB profile"/> the son of Janet Burt (née Crawford) and her husband Alexander Burt, one of the founders of the engineering firm A. & T. Burt Ltd.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=ODT19200103.2.77 | title=Obituary: Mr Alexander Burt | date=3 January 1920 | work=Otago Daily Times | accessdate= 16 January 2016 | page=11}}</ref> Educated at [[Otago Boys' High School]], he then studied at [[Lincoln University (New Zealand)|Canterbury Agricultural College]] and worked for a time in farming.<ref name="John Burt obituary">{{cite news | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=CHP19330117.2.105 | title=Obituary: Mr J. R. Burt | date=17 January 1933 | work=[[The Press]] | volume=LXIX | issue=20756 | accessdate=16 January 2016 | page=13}}</ref> On 23 June 1910, Burt married Elizabeth Rutherford Snow at [[Outram, New Zealand|Outram]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=ODT19100729.2.23 | title=Marriage | date=29 July 1910 | work=Otago Daily Times | accessdate=16 January 2016 | page=4}}</ref> They went on to have two daughters.<ref name="John Burt obituary"/>
==Rugby union== A rugby union [[Rugby union positions#Back row|loose forward]], Burt represented {{Rut Otago}} at a provincial level, playing 11 matches for the side between 1896 and 1901. He played just one match for the New Zealand national side, against {{Rut Wellington}} in 1901.<ref name="AB profile">{{cite web| url = http://stats.allblacks.com/asp/Profile.asp?ABID=117 |title = John Burt | last = Knight | first = Lindsay | publisher = New Zealand Rugby Union | accessdate = 16 January 2016}}</ref>
==Cricket== Burt made three first-class appearances for the Otago cricket team: two in the 1901-02 season and one in the 1908-09 season.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/21/21568/First-Class_Matches.html |title=First-class matches played by John Burt |date= |website= |publisher=CricketArchive |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> A batsman, Burt opened the innings for Otago twice in his four times at bat.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/5/5842.html |title=Canterbury v Otago in 1901/02 |date= |website= |publisher=CricketArchive |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/5/5845.html |title=Otago v Hawke's Bay in 1901/02 |date= |website= |publisher=CricketArchive |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/7/7764.html |title=Hawke's Bay v Otago in 1908/09 |date= |website= |publisher=CricketArchive |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> He scored 72 runs, with a high score of 27, at an average of 18.00, and took two catches.<ref>{{Cricketarchive|id=21568|name=John Burt}}</ref>
==Business career==
After leaving farming, Burt initially worked for A. & T. Burt in Dunedin. He was manager of the firm's Wellington branch from 1908 to 1912, and represented the company in London from 1912 to 1920. Returning to New Zealand, he was manager of A. & T. Burt's Christchurch branch until his retirement in 1932.<ref name="John Burt obituary"/>
==Death== Burt died in [[Christchurch]] on 16 January 1933,<ref name="AB profile"/> and was survived by his wife and their daughters.<ref name="John Burt obituary" /> He was buried at [[Dunedin Northern Cemetery]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dunedin.govt.nz/facilities/cemeteries/cemeteries_search?recordid=88269&type=Burial |title=Cemeteries search |publisher=[[Dunedin City Council]] |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> in the same plot as his parents.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dunedin.govt.nz/facilities/cemeteries/cemeteries_search?recordid=87647&type=Burial |title=Cemeteries search |publisher=[[Dunedin City Council]] |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dunedin.govt.nz/facilities/cemeteries/cemeteries_search?recordid=86521&type=Burial |title=Cemeteries search |publisher=[[Dunedin City Council]] |accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} '''Julio Ariza Irigoyen''', born in [[Carcastillo]], [[Navarra]], Spain in 1957 is a Spanish entrepreneur who currently chairs the [[Intereconomia Media Group|Grupo Intereconomia]]. He was part of the [[People's Party (Spain)|Spanish People's Party]] in Catalonia with [[Alejo Vidal-Quadras]] and a MP in the regional parliament.<ref>{{cite web|title=Julio Ariza|url=http://www.gaceta.es/biografia/julio-ariza|publisher=Gaceta|accessdate=29 April 2014}}</ref>
After his political career in [[Catalonia]], he moved to [[Madrid]] where he acquired [[:es:Radio Intereconomía|Radio Intereconomía]] in 1997, a radio formula based on financial information and classical music. In the following years, it became a reference station in Spain.
Currently, the Group comprises several media like television channels (IntereconomíaTV and Business TV), radio (Radio and Radio Inter Intereconomía) and the newspaper La Gaceta, with a strong conservative and anti-abortion ideology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Father and Death|url=http://elpais.com/autor/julio_ariza_irigoyen/a/|publisher=Elpais|accessdate=29 April 2014}}</ref>
Nowadays, the chairman of Intereconomía usually comments the news in television programs with high audiences that consolidate him as one of the leaders of communication in Spain.

{{Infobox person | name =Jürg Marquard | image = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|7|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Zürich]], [[Switzerland]] | nationality = [[Switzerland|Swiss]] | religion = | residence = Herrliberg, Switzerland | occupation = Founder and Owner, [[Marquard Media]] [[Aktiengesellschaft|AG]] | alma_mater = | country = | networth = CHF 500 Million - 1 Billion }}
'''Jürg Marquard''' (born 13 July 1945 in [[Zürich]]) is a [[Swiss]] publisher. He attended school in Zürich, where he became involved in journalism at a young age. Having done his leaving certificate (Matura) at the “Kantonsschule” for Economics in Zürich, he launched the youth magazine “POP” with SFR 2'000., which he borrowed from school friends. This founded the basis of his journalistic and entrepreneurial career.
At that time Jürg Marquard already sensed that the flourishing pop and rock culture was not just a fly-by-night phenomenon, but also a strong youth movement with revolutionary potential. He sensed this movement would embrace a large spectrum beyond the music and entertainment industry, such as fashion, lifestyle, culture and that it would even penetrate politics.
At the same time as putting his magazine “POP” on the map, Jürg Marquard was also working as a radio and TV presenter, specialising in pop music. He was the first presenter of the Radio-Hit-Parade to achieve great popularity in Switzerland.
==A successful entry into the German-speaking magazine market==
After the eventful early days, in which Jürg Marquard himself edited the magazine with a lot a passion, the magazine became a commercial success. After various mergers with other German youth magazines, POP became POP/ROCKY, which was Germany's second largest youth magazine for many years. POP/ROCKY maintained this status for decades until it was eventually merged with POPCORN in 1998. POPCORN was one of Marquard Media’s international [[umbrella brand]]s.
His big breakthrough in the German-speaking magazine market was achieved with the takeover of COSMOPOLITAN in 1981. Before then the German version of COSMOPOLITAN had been dragging its feet without any noticeable success. With radical editorial changes he turned COSMOPOLITAN into a huge success in less than a year. COSMOPOLITAN led the way for a new type of women's magazine. When taking over COSMOPOLITAN on October 14, 1981, Jürg Marquard said: "I believe in the future of this brand because recent years have brought about deep changes with regards to the self-image and the role behaviour of women. COSMOPOLITAN is the journalistic answer to these changes. The success is therefore pre-determined." COSMOPOLITAN subsequently became the most successful premium women’s magazine in the German-speaking market and therefore the basis for the expansion of the premium lifestyle segment of the Marquard Media Group.
==The internationalisation of Marquard Media==
In 1988 Jürg Marquard launched the [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] versions of POPCORN and MÄDCHEN (Girl). With these launches he became the first western publisher of periodical magazines behind the then still existing “Iron Curtain”. The big success as well as the positive perspectives after the political change made Jürg Marquard invest dynamically in Central European markets and expand his activities – including the acquisition of daily newspapers in Hungary and Poland, as well as launching new magazines. In 1999, during the process of a strategic re-orientation, Jürg Marquard focused his activities on the premium magazine segment and therefore streamlined his portfolio: The youth and music titles were sold to Axel Springer, the Hungarian newspapers to Ringier and the Polish printing house to Baring Private Equity Partners. Following this phase of consolidation Marquard Media again expanded by launching various new magazines as well as taking over and integrating VIPress (PLAYBOY und VOYAGE) in [[Poland]]. In summer 2005, Marquard Media with a successful public offer, secured a 91,4% stake in Computec Media AG, a stock exchange listed publisher of various consumer magazines in the area of Electronic Entertainment and Multi-Media.
In 2005 Jürg Marquard was the co-producer and protagonist of the TV show „Traumjob“, a licensed version of Donald Trumps „The Apprentice“. This was a top-rated show on Kanal 1 on Swiss television.
===Marquard Media today===
In 2012, Marquard Media published 41 magazines in Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Hungary and Poland. It is currently active with license editions in many other countries. The ever-growing online business encompasses 25 websites in the German-speaking markets.
In Hungary, Marquard Media is the leading publisher of premium magazines in the women’s as well as the men’s segment with a wide-ranging portfolio: JOY, EVA, INSTYLE, SHAPE, JOY CELEBRITY, FITT MAMA, PLAYBOY, PLAYBOY EXCLUSIVE, CKM and DESIGN ROOM.
Marquard Media continues to expand in the premium magazine segment in Poland. With CKM and PLAYBOY, it is the leading publisher in the men’s segment and also holds a top position in the women’s premium segment with COSMOPOLITAN, JOY, OLIVIA and SHAPE as well as with the travel magazine VOYAGE. Marquard Media is also successfully represented in the segment of weekly women’s magazines and true-stories magazines in Poland with PANI DOMU, CIENIE I BLASKI und SEKRETY SERCA.
Jürg Marquard plans to keep expanding his company. Further expansion is occurring via new launches, as well as further acquisitions.
==Shareholdings==
His total shareholding in London FTSE listed Kea Petroleum is 29,033,253 ordinary shares representing 4.16% of the Company's current voting rights.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Konstantin Chuychenko | native_name = Константин Чуйченко | native_name_lang = ru | image = Konstantin_Chuychenko_official_portrait.png | caption = | alt = | office = [[Deputy Prime Minister of Russia]] – Chief of Staff of the Government | term_start = 18 May 2018 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Sergei Eduardovich Prikhodko|Sergey Prikhodko]] | successor = | office2 = Head of the Control Department in the Russian Presidential Administration | term_start2 = 13 May 2008 | term_end2 = 18 May 2018 | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | president2 = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|7|12|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Lipetsk]], [[Lipetsk Oblast]], [[Soviet Union]]
{{small|(now [[Russia]])}} | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = | party = [[United Russia]] }} '''Konstantin Anatolyevich Chuychenko''' ({{Lang-ru|Константин Анатольевич Чуйченко}}; born 12 July 1965) is a Russian politician, businessman, and lawyer serving as the [[Deputy Prime Minister of Russia]] and Chief of Staff of the Government since 2018. == Career == Born in [[Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union]], Chuychenko graduated from the Law Department of [[Leningrad State University]] in 1987 as a fellow student of [[Dmitry Medvedev]].{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUKL1439741520080514|title=Medvedev names key advisers and most are Putin men|date=14 May 2008|agency=Reuters |accessdate=5 February 2010}} From 1989 to 1992 Chuychenko served in the [[KGB]].{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,537864-3,00.html|title=The Anointed One:Tracking the Rise of Putin's Crown Prince|date=26 February 2008|work=Der Spiegel |accessdate=5 February 2010}} In March 2001 he became the Chief of the Legal Department of [[Gazprom]] and since April 2002 he has been a member of the management committee of Gazprom.{{cite web|url=http://eng.kremlin.ru/subj/201295.shtml|title=Konstantin Chuychenko – Kremlin profile|accessdate=5 February 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} From 17 January 2003 to July 2004 he was the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the [[Gazprom Media]] holding. Since March 2003 he has been a member of the board of directors of the [[TNT Russia|TNT]] TV network. He is also a member of the board of directors of [[Gazprom Media]],{{cite news|url=http://unian.net/eng/news/news-240453.html|title=Ukraine agrees to buy gas from Russia at US $321 for thousand cu m|date=3 November 2008|publisher=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|''UNIAN'']]|accessdate=5 February 2010}} [[NTV Russia|NTV]] and a shareholder of Gazprom. Since July 2004 he has been an executive director of [[RosUkrEnergo]] representing [[Gazprombank]]. Since 23 December 2005, he has been a member of the board of directors of [[Sibneft]] (now Gazprom Neft).{{cite web|url=http://www.gazprom-neft.com/press-center/press-releases/?id=648|title=Sibneft Shareholders Choose New President, Board of Directors|date=23 December 2005|publisher=[[Gazprom Neft]]|accessdate=5 February 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chuychenko, Konstantin}} [[Category:Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:Russian lawyers]] [[Category:KGB officers]] [[Category:Medvedev Administration personnel]] [[Category:Gazprom people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1965 births]]

{{EngvarB|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Kutubuddin Ahmed | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1956|1|21}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Kutubuddin Ahmed''' (born 1956) is a [[Bangladesh]]i businessman who is the founder and chairman of the Envoy Group,<ref name="ds5Dec2014" /> a conglomerate which operates in multiple sectors, with major operation in the apparel industry.<ref name="reuters">[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/10/20/uk-bangladesh-politics-idUKBRE99J03520131020 "Elections in jeopardy as Bangladesh parties head for showdown"]. ''Reuters'', 20 October 2013, DHAKA | By Shyamantha Asokan and Serajul Quadir</ref> He is a Fellow of the Institute of Engineers, Bangladesh. In 2015 he is a member of the executive committee of the International Chamber of Commerce, Bangladesh, and a director of the Chittagong Stock Exchange.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
==Early life and education== Ahmed was born on 21 January 1956 in [[Dhaka]]. He graduated in mechanical engineering from [[Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology]] (BUET).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iccbangladesh.org.bd/committee/details/kutubuddin-ahmed |title=Executive Board: Kutubuddin Ahmed |website=International Chamber of Commerce Bangladesh |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref>
==Business career== Ahmed began his career at [[Janata Bank]], but resigned in 1983 to start his own business. Raising the BDT 10 lakh (US$37,500 in 1984) initial capital for what is now known as the [[Envoy Group]] proved difficult. In the end, Ahmed took out a bank loan with his father's house as collateral and brought in a partner, [[Abdus Salam Murshedy]],<ref name="ds20May2017">{{cite news |last=Mirdha |first=Refayet Ullah |date=20 May 2017 |title=Fortune favours the brave |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/supplements/fortune-favours-the-brave-1407907 |newspaper=The Daily Star |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref> a [[striker (football)|striker]] for [[Mohammedan Sporting Club (Dhaka)|Mohammedan Sporting Club]] who had gained fame in 1982 by scoring a league-record 27 goals, but who had no previous business experience.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wedson's near miss |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/wedsons-near-miss-34787 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=25 July 2014 |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.envoy-group.com/md-profile.php |title=Managing Director's Profile: Abdus Salam Murshedy |website=Envoy Group |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref>
In 1984, the partners set up a small factory in the [[Khilgaon Thana]] area of Dhaka, equipped it with 46 sewing machines, and hired 200 garment workers. Initially the company sub-contracted for other garment manufacturers.<ref name="ds20May2017" /> They were early participants in a sector that would become a powerhouse of the Bangladesh economy,<ref name="ds5Dec2014">{{cite news |last=Mirdha |first=Refayet Ullah |date=5 December 2014 |title=From baby steps to giant strides |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/from-baby-steps-to-giant-strides-53432 |newspaper=The Daily Star |access-date=9 July 2017}}</ref> but orders were sporadic at first, and the factory was idle for long spells. Sometimes they had to borrow from banks to meet payroll. The turning point came when they received their first order as a primary contractor, 6,500 trousers for a Swedish retailer.<ref name="ds20May2017" />
The agent who placed the order was impressed with their work and directed more business their way. In the next 16 months, Envoy Group recorded a BDT 1 crore (US$385,000 in 1985) profit. They paid off their debt and bought two more garment factories, building on the experience gained running their first.<ref name="ds20May2017" />
Through expansion, by attracting investment and purchasing existing businesses, Ahmed led the company as it grew over the years into a large manufacturing and exporting group.<ref>[http://www.thedailystar.net/business/envoy-textiles-raises-tk-70cr-through-commercial-papers-1205938 "Envoy Textiles raises Tk 70cr through commercial papers"]. ''The Daily Star'', 8 April 2016</ref>
Ahmed completed a term as President in Metropolitan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI), Dhaka and Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers & Exporters Association (BGMEA) in 2001 and 2002.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1482751.stm "Inquiry into Dhaka stampede"]. ''BBC News''. Kamal Ahmed</ref><ref>[http://www.sdnbd.org/sdi/news/general-news/July/21-07-2002/Business.htm "Businessmen urged to capture global market"]. Chittagong, ''The Daily Star'', as reprinted in ''Sustainable Network Development Network'', Business news, 21 July 2002</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Textile Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=39y5AAAAIAAJ|year=2003|publisher=Business Press|page=114}} Volume 34, Issues 1–6</ref>
He received the "Arthakantha Business Award-2002" by a national financial fortnightly of Bangladesh. He served as president (2004–2005) of the Metropolitan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI), Dhaka, Bangladesh<ref>[http://www.bangladesh-web.com/view.php?hidRecord=31015 "Kutubuddin Ahmed re-elected MCCI President"]. ''News from Bangladesh'' 31 December 2004</ref> He received an outstanding achievement award from International Islamic University Chittagong in 2008.
In 2014, Envoy Group had grown to include manufacturers and exporters garments,name=<ref name="reuters" /><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/21/us-bangladesh-garments-wage-idUSBRE99K02M20131021 "Bangladesh poised to hike garment wages, but may not end strikes"]. ''Reuters'', DHAKA | By Shyamantha Asokan</ref> textiles,<ref>[http://www.denimsandjeans.com/news/interview-with-mr-kutubuddin-ahmed-chairman-envoy-textiles-limited/15854 "Interview With Mr Kutubuddin Ahmed | Chairman , Envoy Textiles Limited"]. ''Denims and Jeans'', SANDEEP AGGARWAL 13 September 2015</ref> Real Estate, Freight Forwarding, information technology and computer systems operations. At that time the company was employing about 20,000 people,<ref name="ds5Dec2014" /> and had received several awards, including the President's Export Trophy, and the National Export Trophy. In 2015, Ahmed was named a "commercially important person" by the government of Bangladesh.<ref>[http://archive.dhakatribune.com/business/2015/apr/28/56-individuals-get-cip-status-fy14 "56 individuals to get CIP status for FY14"]. ''Dhaka Tribune'', 28 April 2015</ref>
==Sports== Ahmed is a former President of both the Bangladesh Mohammedan Sporting Club, Dhaka, and the Bangladesh Badminton Federation. He was awarded 1997 "Sport Organizer of the Year" by Bangladesh Journalist Association, and received "National Sports Award 2002" for his contribution as a sports organiser in Bangladesh. In 2006 he was awarded the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) Trophy for "Sports and the Community", and also Best Sports Organizer by Bangladesh Sports Writers' Association.<ref>[http://www.thedailystar.net/sports/pm-hands-out-sports-awards-1280392 "PM hands out sports awards for 2010, 2011 and 2012"]. ''Daily Star''. 4 September 2016</ref>
In 2009, Ahmed served as the secretary-general of the Bangladesh Olympic Association.<ref>[http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/cricket-to-feature-in-2010-south-asian-games/424632/ "Cricket to feature in 2010 South Asian Games"]. ''Reuters '' Dhaka, 17 February 2009.</ref> In 2014, he is a member of the Sports Environment Committee, Olympic Council of Asia (OCA), and the Vice-President of the International Military Sports Council (CISM).
==Community activity==
Ahmed formed "Saadat Smriti Sadan" charitable foundation in memory of his father Md. Saadat Ali. He established two Clinics which provide free medical treatment to the poor and distressed people. He set up a retirement home, ''Old-Homes'' for aged people over 65 years in Narshindi, Dhaka.
Ahmed funded the building of a Mosque at Nabi Nagar Thana, Comilla, and established a Technical Institute with computer accessories and sewing machinery tools in Narshindi for providing technical training. He is an advisor to the Campaign against Drug being run by the daily newspaper "Prothom Alo", and a member of the Advisory Council of the children's organisation 'Kendriya Kochi Kacher Mela'.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.envoy-group.com Envoy Group website]
